awd_titl_txt: Conference: Supporting Mentoring in STEM Graduate Education: A Proposal for Virtual Workshops and Supporting Activities
awd_abstract_narration:
Through this project, the Council of Graduate Schools (CGS) will host two virtual workshops in 2024 that will inform the readiness of principal investigators to respond to NSF's new PAPPG requirements implemented in response to the America COMPETES Act of 2022 and the CHIPS and Science Act of 2022. Specifically, the workshops will address NSF requirements: (1) that all proposals to NSF include mentoring plans for all graduate students on NSF funded awards; (2) that institutions provide mentor training and mentorship and describe in grant proposals a plan to provide appropriate training and oversight in the Responsible and Ethical Conduct of Research; and (3) that each individual postdoctoral scholar and graduate student receiving substantial NSF support must have an Individual Development Plan, updated annually. The first workshop will focus on faculty researchers while the second will focus on graduate deans and other administrators who have responsibilities for expanding and enhancing graduate mentorship training across STEM fields. 

The proposal will fund the identification, development, and dissemination of mentoring resources and tools as well as promising practices and policies to enhance graduate mentoring and assist institutions and individual faculty in responding to the new NSF requirements. The resulting resources will address an important need for an accessible set of resources on evidence-based and promising practices and policies in graduate mentorship. A central goal of this proposal is to provide more accessible resources on effective mentoring to a broad range of institutions and universities serving diverse populations and in EPSCoR jurisdictions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The National Science Foundation (NSF) has required a mentoring plan for postdoctoral grantees since 2007, and this requirement is now being extended to those applying for grants which include graduate students. This broadening of the mentoring requirement is a furthering of NSFs acknowledgement of the importance of mentoring and mentorship in the graduate students’ experience, and in the formation of their future goals. The Council of Graduate Schools (CGS) is the premier organization dedicated to the advancement of graduate education and research. Therefore, CGS was in an ideal position to 1/ educate the graduate community about the NSF’s requirement and 2/ to provide tools to the graduate community to enhance the graduate communities’ access to mentoring resources.

 

Our responsibility for the grant was to produce two webinars and a set of curated resources. Our first webinar, which was directed toward Deans and Vice Presidents of Research (VPR), took place on 4/23/24 and had record registrations with 1,259 registrants and 975 total attendees. In addition, the recording has been viewed 951 times, to date, on YouTube (Jan 2025). The webinar (see recording here) featured presentations from NSF leadership sharing details about NSF’s new graduate student mentoring requirements. The workshop also included graduate deans, and a Vice President for Research, who have prepared their Principal, and prospective Investigators (PIs) to meet those NSF requirements.

 

  • Sylvia Butterfield, Deputy Assistant Director, Directorate for STEM Education (EDU), National Science Foundation
  • Daniel Denecke, Lead Program Director, Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE), NSF
  • Ellen Fisher, Vice President for Research, University of New Mexico
  • Debra Jackson, Associate Vice President for Academic Affairs and Dean of Academic Programs, California State University, Bakersfield
  • Mike Solomon, Dean, Graduate Studies and Vice Provost for Academic Affairs, University of Michigan

 

Our second webinar, Faculty/ PI Workshop: How NSF’s New Mentoring Requirements Can Improve Your Research Agenda, (see recording here) took place on 6/18/2024. This webinar was directed toward PIs interested in enhancing their understanding of the new requirements. For this webinar, we had 516 registrants and 309 total attendees. As of this date, the recording has also been viewed an additional 224 times (Jan 2025).

  • Jacqueline Huntoon,  Director, Division of Graduate Education (DGE) at NSF and 
  • Daniel Denecke, Lead Program Director, Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE), NSF
  • Ricardo Cortez, Pendegraft William Larkin Duren Professor of Mathematics, Tulane University
  • Adam Matzger, Charles G. Overberger Collegiate Professor of Chemistry and Macromolecular Science and Engineering, University of Michigan
  • Ruth Varner, Professor of Biogeochemistry, University of New Hampshire
  • Corrie Kuniyoshi, Portfolio Manager, Student Experiences Office, American Chemical Society, and PI of NSF IGE grant, Impact Indicators and Instruments for Individual Development Plans (IDPs)

In addition to hosting the two webinars, we also created a frequently asked questions (FAQ) and a set of mentoring resources, which is hosted on the CGS website. https://cgsnet.org/data-insights/graduate-professional-development/mentoring-resources.  As discussed in the webinar on 4/23/2024, NSF recognizes there are a wide variety of mentoring models being used across higher education, therefore, they have not endorsed any particular approach to articulate one’s mentoring plan(s). Examples of mentoring activities include, but are not limited to: career counseling; training in preparation of grant proposals, publications and presentations; guidance on ways to improve teaching and mentoring skills; guidance on how to effectively collaborate with researchers from diverse backgrounds and disciplinary areas; and training in responsible professional practices”. (https://nsf-gov-resources.nsf.gov/2022-10/nsf23_1.pdf?VersionId=VQHMy1XFClNhULRMabdaeCqYvbgykldV II-32)

 

Since the mentoring pages launched, they've been collectively viewed 2,406 times so far by 1,118 users, with 2.15 views per user. This indicates that members of the graduate community are coming back to these pages multiple times, which means it is being seen as a valuable resource. The Council of Graduate Schools has utilized multiple communication mechanisms to communicate about the webinars and the resources available, i.e., multiple emails to the community, posts on social media (LinkedIn) and through our annual summer meeting. Dr. Cari Moorhead (PI), presented a mentoring workshop at the 2024 CGS annual meeting, where she further disseminated information on the webinars and resource pages. Given NSF’s interest in quality mentorship, it is important to note that the most popular sub-page is For Mentors, indicating that the majority of the visitors to our pages are mentors looking to improve their mentorship.

 

While we don’t have the insight into the ripple effect of the webinars and the resources across the board, we do know the work is having an ongoing impact, in broad terms e.g., through a citation  in an upcoming CGS SCOTUS report and on particular campuses, e.g., the University of New Hampshire has launched its mentoring program in January 2025, which draws from the webinars and resources that resulted from this grant.

Modified by: Suzanne T Ortega
